children.subject: Thanks for the info! What you said seems to match my guess: I probably have less of a knowledge gap for 186 and that'll be easier for me to do.
Ya have a blast in 186 it has the best staff and you’ll get great experience with the 4 java projects. You got this!
I appreciate the advice and encouragement Farid!

I'd say that you can pretty comfortably do 186 as long as you get comfortable with Java. I took it at the same time as 61C and there wasn't too much overlap, just some concepts of caching (nothing intricate).

162 I would say requires quite a bit from 61C. You would need to brush up on virtual memory and address translation, thread-level parallelism (maybe not quite as much), and caching (here's the Fall '18 website if you want to check out the topics covered in 61C). It also helps a lot to be very comfortable with C since all of the projects and assignments are in C.

history.content:
I'm a transfer who's going to be doing my 5th semester in Fall 2019. I will only be taking 1 CS class in the fall and I'm deciding between 186 and 162 since both seem relevant to Software Engineering.

  • Which one of the two will give me more knowledge (that is relevant to SWE)?
  • For either class, I'm likely missing some relevant knowledge, so I'm wondering what knowledge from 61B and 61C will be relevant for 186 and 162 respectively? Also, is it feasible to self-study that missing knowledge over this summer? (I'll be doing an internship then)
    • My background: My 61B-equivalent CC class was in C++. I've made some Android apps before (not very organized code) and I did some backend web dev in Java in a prior internship. I've only formally learned Java from AP CS and a Udacity course. My 61C-equivalent CC class mostly just taught how to program in x86.
history.subject: Readiness for CS 186/162
